description: The Honduras judiciary has suspended work from March 23-March 29 and deemed those days as "unusual" for the purposes of proceedings and procedural deadlines. Most essential personnel will telework, however essential personell who are required to be physically at work, including limited people of the courts that deal with criminal matters, children, and domestic violence will be at work on a rotational bases. Personnel will only go into work to deal with matters of extreme urgency and to receive paperwork such as the delivery of alimony. Pregnant women, people over age 60, people with immune deficiencies, or other at risk diseases will not be allowed to rotate into work. All scheduled hearings during these dates will be rescheduled.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: The Honduran president issued an executive order for more than 70 state institutions, especially those that generate income, to present their smart reopening plan in order to open asap. In their reopening plans they must outline how they will apply all requires biosafety protocols. Employees are expected to return to work, but there are exceptions for people over age 60, pregnant women, cancer or cancer treatment patients, and people with hypertension, diabetes, or kidney disease. In the reopening plan each institution must give the name and address of employees who will be returning to work. It also must include a number of people who live with them. Institutions must also follow the 10-4 rule: they will work for 4 days and are off for 10 days to ensure they do not have symptoms.
